<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" media="screen" href="/~d/styles/rss2full.xsl"?><?xml-stylesheet type="text/css" media="screen" href="http://feeds.gawker.com/~d/styles/itemcontent.css"?><rss xmlns:itunes="http://www.itunes.com/dtds/podcast-1.0.dtd" xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:taxo="http://purl.org/rss/1.0/modules/taxonomy/" xmlns:rdf="http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#" xmlns:atom="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" xmlns:wfw="http://wellformedweb.org/CommentAPI/" xmlns:feedburner="http://rssnamespace.org/feedburner/ext/1.0" version="2.0"><channel><title>io9</title><link>http://io9.gizmodo.com</link><description>We come from the future.</description><language>en</language><atom10:link xmlns:atom10="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" rel="self" type="application/rss+xml" href="http://feeds.gawker.com/io9/full" /><feedburner:info uri="io9/full" /><atom10:link xmlns:atom10="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" rel="hub" href="http://pubsubhubbub.appspot.com/" /><item><title>Just Four Minutes of Matthew McConaughey Making Weird Noises</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/e8LM6E_FyxU/just-four-minutes-of-matthew-mcconaughey-making-weird-n-1776342095</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--d93S8Ka9--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/xmahsf2rh2wnjvvg7ion.gif" /><p class="first-text">The same folks who realized Owen Wilson is <a href="http://sploid.gizmodo.com/video-all-the-times-owen-wilson-has-said-wow-in-movies-1703678308">contractually obligated to say “wow” in every film</a>
 <inset id="1703678308" /> have stumbled upon something truly strange: Matthew McConaughey makes a lot of noises. Noises that are not words. Noises that do not convey almost any information other than “I am Matthew McConaughey and my mouth can make this sound.”</p><p><a href="http://sploid.gizmodo.com/just-four-minutes-of-matthew-mcconaughey-making-weird-n-1776342095">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/e8LM6E_FyxU" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">grawwwwww</category><category domain="">matthew mcconaughey</category><category domain="">movies</category><category domain="">actors</category><category domain="">alright alright alright</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 21:10:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776342095</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Bryan Menegus on Sploid, shared by Cheryl Eddy to io9]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://sploid.gizmodo.com/just-four-minutes-of-matthew-mcconaughey-making-weird-n-1776342095</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Watch a Spear Get Forged Using Centuries-Old Methods</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/pPsVkHTAlOE/watch-a-spear-get-forged-using-century-old-methods-1776296378</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--n5Cu2eKT--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/fi0n2sqshrtj4vlbg4tb.gif" /><figure class="has-media media-medium has-image">
 <img src="http://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--Er5RaBQb--/fi0n2sqshrtj4vlbg4tb.gif" width="640" height="290" alt="Watch a Spear Get Forged Using Centuries-Old Methods" lazyload="true" data-chomp-id="fi0n2sqshrtj4vlbg4tb" data-asset-url="http://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--Er5RaBQb--/fi0n2sqshrtj4vlbg4tb.gif" data-format="gif" firstasset="true" />
</figure>
<p class="first-text">To make a spearhead like a Norman smith from the year 1066, you have to start with an iron steel sandwich. Yup, a piece of hard iron or steel gets sandwiched between two pieces of soft iron until they’re all hammered and welded together. After that, a socket needs to be made, which means the smith flattens out the metal wide enough so it can be folded into a circle to stick a wooden shaft in.</p><p><a href="http://sploid.gizmodo.com/watch-a-spear-get-forged-using-century-old-methods-1776296378">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/pPsVkHTAlOE" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">neat</category><category domain="">forging</category><category domain="">metal</category><category domain="">weapons</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 21:30:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776296378</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Casey Chan on Sploid, shared by Cheryl Eddy to io9]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://sploid.gizmodo.com/watch-a-spear-get-forged-using-century-old-methods-1776296378</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Interesting Portrait of an Actor Who Plays Monsters in Movies</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/sInWP-t2wMA/interesting-portrait-of-an-actor-who-plays-monsters-in-1776170134</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--UspF0rMc--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/ifcpuurujhvihuop6tnn.gif" /><figure class="has-media media-medium has-image">
 <img src="http://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--8YrqWrQ7--/ifcpuurujhvihuop6tnn.gif" width="640" height="310" alt="Interesting Portrait of an Actor Who Plays Monsters in Movies" lazyload="true" data-chomp-id="ifcpuurujhvihuop6tnn" data-asset-url="http://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--8YrqWrQ7--/ifcpuurujhvihuop6tnn.gif" data-format="gif" firstasset="true" />
</figure>
<p class="first-text">Meet Tom Woodruff. You’ve seen him in movies but probably didn’t even realize he was in them because he specializes in playing creatures. That is, he’s been the alien in <em>Aliens, </em>a gorilla in various TV shows and movies, done work for <em>Jumanji</em>, and so much more. What’s cool is to hear him talk about his craft and process and to see him act it out in an actual suit versus doing motion capture (not that there’s anything wrong with that). </p><p><a href="http://sploid.gizmodo.com/interesting-portrait-of-an-actor-who-plays-monsters-in-1776170134">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/sInWP-t2wMA" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">neat</category><category domain="">monsters</category><category domain="">movies</category><category domain="">actors</category><category domain="">acting</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 02:34:51 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776170134</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Casey Chan on Sploid, shared by Cheryl Eddy to io9]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://sploid.gizmodo.com/interesting-portrait-of-an-actor-who-plays-monsters-in-1776170134</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Sources: The Ambitious (Now Cancelled) Plans For Disney Infinity's Future Included Rogue One, Bigger Figures</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/lIj-skFWxn8/sources-the-ambitious-now-cancelled-plans-for-disney-1776370484</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--QbdTLeVP--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/mlr1h6gdnv5ig0pnymyp.png" /><p class="first-text">Disney’s cancellation of its lucrative toy-centric <em>Disney Infinity </em>series is even more shocking given the tantalizing plans for the series that two sources close to the project have shared with <em>Kotaku</em>.</p><p><a href="http://kotaku.com/sources-the-ambitious-now-cancelled-plans-for-disney-1776370484">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/lIj-skFWxn8" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">disney infinity</category><category domain="">kotaku core</category><category domain="">disney</category><category domain="">disney infinity 40</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 23:10:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776370484</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Patrick Klepek on Kotaku, shared by Cheryl Eddy to io9]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://kotaku.com/sources-the-ambitious-now-cancelled-plans-for-disney-1776370484</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Report: Russia Led a State-Run Doping Program for the 2014 Sochi Olympics</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/Xz8fCTa7eEY/report-russia-ran-a-state-run-doping-program-for-2014-1776309774</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--0obuEUzd--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/avd5uy6m3j7idupygelr.jpg" /><p class="first-text"><em>The New York Times</em> <a href="http://mobile.nytimes.com/2016/05/13/sports/russia-doping-sochi-olympics-2014.html" rel="noopener" target="_blank">published a blistering expos&eacute; </a>today, detailing how Russian Olympians engaged in a state-run doping program in order to win as many gold medals as possible during the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi. At least 15 medal winners were reportedly involved. </p><p><a href="http://gizmodo.com/report-russia-ran-a-state-run-doping-program-for-2014-1776309774">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/Xz8fCTa7eEY" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">drugs</category><category domain="">sochi</category><category domain="">olympics</category><category domain="">sports</category><category domain="">doping</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 19:05:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776309774</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Darren Orf on Gizmodo, shared by Cheryl Eddy to io9]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://gizmodo.com/report-russia-ran-a-state-run-doping-program-for-2014-1776309774</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Disney's New Telepresence Robot Is So Precise it Can Be Used to Thread a Needle</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/v1zmDOz60Hk/disneys-new-telepresence-robot-is-so-precise-it-can-be-1776272736</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--nUKmBb2O--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/qee3jlvqmnq722ejsc13.gif" /><p class="first-text">The easiest way to make a robot as dexterous and capable as a human being is to simply let a human control it. That’s how <a href="https://www.disneyresearch.com/publication/haptic-telepresence-robot/" rel="noopener" target="_blank">Disney Research’s new telepresence robot</a> works, but with improved hydraulics on board, it’s now capable of duplicating a human’s motions with remarkable precision—to the point where it can even be used to remotely thread a needle.</p><p><a href="http://gizmodo.com/disneys-new-telepresence-robot-is-so-precise-it-can-be-1776272736">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/v1zmDOz60Hk" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">robots</category><category domain="">research</category><category domain="">disney</category><category domain="">disney research</category><category domain="">technology</category><category domain="">telepresence</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:43:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776272736</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Andrew Liszewski on Gizmodo, shared by Cheryl Eddy to io9]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://gizmodo.com/disneys-new-telepresence-robot-is-so-precise-it-can-be-1776272736</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>The Art of Making Impossibly Thin Gold Leaves from a Tiny Piece of Gold</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/bv1Vq6CQIzk/the-art-of-making-an-impossibly-thin-gold-leaf-from-a-t-1776331400</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--Cl4sC9eP--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/qwfyttcdooyudmdyaexf.gif" /><figure class="has-media media-medium has-image">
 <img src="http://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--Fgoo-XWG--/qwfyttcdooyudmdyaexf.gif" width="640" height="283" alt="The Art of Making Impossibly Thin Gold Leaves from a Tiny Piece of Gold" lazyload="true" data-chomp-id="qwfyttcdooyudmdyaexf" data-asset-url="http://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--Fgoo-XWG--/qwfyttcdooyudmdyaexf.gif" data-format="gif" firstasset="true" />
</figure>
<p class="first-text">Gold is so malleable that a single gram of it can be stretched into a strip nearly two miles long. A tiny little coin can be pressed into a 0.0001-millimeter-thin golden rectangular sheet the size of a tatami mat. So leave it to the talented artisans of Japan to transform a tiny bit of gold into shimmering gold leaf that’s so thin, it’s almost translucent. </p><p><a href="http://sploid.gizmodo.com/the-art-of-making-an-impossibly-thin-gold-leaf-from-a-t-1776331400">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/bv1Vq6CQIzk" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">neat</category><category domain="">gold</category><category domain="">metal</category><category domain="">paper</category><category domain="">japan</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 20:20:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776331400</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Casey Chan on Sploid, shared by Cheryl Eddy to io9]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://sploid.gizmodo.com/the-art-of-making-an-impossibly-thin-gold-leaf-from-a-t-1776331400</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Someone Is Trying to Make Movies Out of Centipede and Missile Command</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/Eh7QbLbfwmQ/someone-is-trying-to-make-movies-out-of-centipede-and-m-1776365147</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--f0aJO1di--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/hstgxubf3nb22ppuufkp.jpg" /><p class="first-text">Trace the history of video games back to its roots and, near the beginning, you’ll find Atari’s <em>Centipede </em>and<em> Missile Command</em>. The shoot-em-up games were early pioneers of the genre, and now they’re catching up with modern games by getting their very own movies.</p><p><a href="http://io9.gizmodo.com/someone-is-trying-to-make-movies-out-of-centipede-and-m-1776365147">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/Eh7QbLbfwmQ" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">centipede</category><category domain="">missile command</category><category domain="">atari</category><category domain="">movies</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 23:30:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776365147</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Germain Lussier]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://io9.gizmodo.com/someone-is-trying-to-make-movies-out-of-centipede-and-m-1776365147</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>ABC Has Canceled Marvel's Agent Carter</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/sKTVR_qw07o/abc-has-cancelled-marvels-agent-carter-1776366639</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--cYJg6COB--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/na33llejpvn8y1xnquds.jpg" /><p class="first-text">After two seasons of fighting crime, <em>Agent Carter</em> has been given her walking papers. The ABC show, based on a character from the Marvel Cinematic Universe, has been canceled.</p><p><a href="http://io9.gizmodo.com/abc-has-cancelled-marvels-agent-carter-1776366639">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/sKTVR_qw07o" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">agent carter</category><category domain="">hayley atwell</category><category domain="">television</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 22:49:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776366639</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Germain Lussier]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://io9.gizmodo.com/abc-has-cancelled-marvels-agent-carter-1776366639</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>MIT Wants You to Swallow This Origami Robot Pill to Retrieve Other Crap You've Swallowed</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/6GINGTkg1t0/mit-wants-you-to-swallow-this-origami-robot-pill-to-ret-1776329221</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--ShrCjuQi--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/oz4g2fl9pyuhly5carur.gif" /><p class="first-text">According to MIT, Americans swallow over 3,500 button-sized batteries every year. Say what? But instead of educating the public about <em>not</em> swallowing random crap, researchers at the school want people to swallow a new <a href="http://news.mit.edu/2016/ingestible-origami-robot-0512" rel="noopener" target="_blank">folding origami robot they’ve developed</a> that’s designed to retrieve foreign objects, among other tasks.<br /></p><p><a href="http://gizmodo.com/mit-wants-you-to-swallow-this-origami-robot-pill-to-ret-1776329221">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/6GINGTkg1t0" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">robots</category><category domain="">mit</category><category domain="">research</category><category domain="">pills</category><category domain="">medical</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 20:18:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776329221</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Andrew Liszewski on Gizmodo, shared by Cheryl Eddy to io9]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://gizmodo.com/mit-wants-you-to-swallow-this-origami-robot-pill-to-ret-1776329221</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Suicide Squad's Joel Kinnaman Will Star In Netflix's Altered Carbon Series</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/8LArcZBklr4/suicide-squads-joel-kinnaman-will-star-in-netflixs-alte-1776322929</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--en1bsJ1Q--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/ue9vjsfcircujflki8zh.jpg" /><p class="p1 first-text">He’s already played a rebooted RoboCop and will next be seen as Rick Flag in <em>Suicide Squad</em>, but now Joel Kinnaman—a Swede whose big U.S. break was cop drama <em>The Killing</em>—is returning to the small screen. He’s set to star in Netflix’s series <em>Altered Carbon</em>, an adaptation of Richard Morgan’s gritty cyberpunk classic.<br /></p><p><a href="http://io9.gizmodo.com/suicide-squads-joel-kinnaman-will-star-in-netflixs-alte-1776322929">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/8LArcZBklr4" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">joel kinnaman</category><category domain="">altered carbon</category><category domain="">netflix</category><category domain="">richard morgan</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 22:00:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776322929</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Cheryl Eddy]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://io9.gizmodo.com/suicide-squads-joel-kinnaman-will-star-in-netflixs-alte-1776322929</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Today's Best Deals: Free Channels, Pyrex Dishes, Bluetooth Headphones, and More</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/_JTL0n4qc-g/todays-best-deals-free-hdtv-pyrex-dishes-bluetooth-h-1776234799</link><description><img href="http://www.amazon.com/AmazonBasics-Ultra-Thin-Indoor-Antenna/dp/B00X4RAEZC/" rel="noopener" target="_blank">amplified HDTV antenna</a>, <a href="http://www.amazon.com/Pyrex-8-Piece-Glass-Bakeware-Storage/dp/B004CFY55A?kinja_price=15" rel="noopener" target="_blank">Pyrex dishes</a>, and a <a href="http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00Q2B5KY2" rel="noopener" target="_blank">clever USB battery pack</a> lead off Thursday’s best deals.</p><p><a href="http://deals.kinja.com/todays-best-deals-free-hdtv-pyrex-dishes-bluetooth-h-1776234799">Read domain="">deals</category><category domain="">daily deals</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 13:56:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776234799</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Shep McAllister on Deals, shared by Shep McAllister to io9]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://deals.kinja.com/todays-best-deals-free-hdtv-pyrex-dishes-bluetooth-h-1776234799</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Hubble Just Caught a Close-Up View of What Flying Into an Active Comet Looks Like</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/i1ivSf6LmIg/hubble-just-caught-a-close-up-view-of-what-flying-into-1776343521</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--eLTUp3mu--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/tcig19kbpnmdamhm9n2l.gif" /><p class="first-text">Comets brush by us all the time, but they’re usually not close enough for us to catch anything more than a glimpse as they streak through the sky. But, thanks to one very close comet, Hubble just got an incredible insider view.</p><p><a href="http://gizmodo.com/hubble-just-caught-a-close-up-view-of-what-flying-into-1776343521">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/i1ivSf6LmIg" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">space</category><category domain="">comets</category><category domain="">science</category><category domain="">nasa</category><category domain="">meteor shower</category><category domain="">meteors</category><category domain="">comet 252p</category><category domain="">comet linear</category><category domain="">comet 252plinear</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 21:05:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776343521</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Ria Misra on Gizmodo, shared by Cheryl Eddy to io9]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://gizmodo.com/hubble-just-caught-a-close-up-view-of-what-flying-into-1776343521</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Deadspin Dayton Center Steve McElvene Dies At 20 | The Slot Join 100 Women Posing Naked at the Repub</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/4mncWYHcRds/deadspin-dayton-center-steve-mcelvene-dies-at-20-the-1776347069</link><description><p class="first-text"><strong>Deadspin</strong> <a href="http://deadspin.com/dayton-center-steve-mcelvene-dies-at-20-1776325750?utm_source=recirculation&amp;utm_medium=recirculation&amp;utm_campaign=thursdayPM" rel="noopener" target="_blank">Dayton Center Steve McElvene Dies At 20</a>

This is everything you need to know to starting watching the adventures of Steven and the Crystal Gems immediately. (Because you really, really should.)</p><p><a href="http://io9.gizmodo.com/everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-wonderful-world-o-1776328081">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/MpQkswBwGN8" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">steven universe</category><category domain="">backgrounder</category><category domain="">guide</category><category domain="">animation</category><category domain="">rebecca sugar</category><category domain="">cartoon network</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 20:45:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776328081</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[James Whitbrook]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://io9.gizmodo.com/everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-wonderful-world-o-1776328081</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>DARPA's Mind-Controlled Arm Will Make You Wish You Were a Cyborg</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/SmNLlwu_JKE/darpas-mind-controlled-arm-will-make-you-wish-you-were-1776130193</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--GByQAlzH--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/mdbscxrgplrpbvjpx3dq.jpg" /><p class="first-text">When I asked Johnny Matheny if I could shake his hand, I was admittedly a little nervous. The soft-spoken Floridian lost his lower left arm to cancer eight years back. His new arm—an advanced, mind-controlled prosthetic developed by DARPA—can crush a human human skull like a child squeezing a clementine.<br /></p><p><a href="http://gizmodo.com/darpas-mind-controlled-arm-will-make-you-wish-you-were-1776130193">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/SmNLlwu_JKE" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">neuroscience</category><category domain="">prosthetics</category><category domain="">neuroprosthetics</category><category domain="">darpa</category><category domain="">science</category><category domain="">robotics</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 20:04:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776130193</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Maddie Stone on Gizmodo, shared by Adam Clark Estes to io9]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://gizmodo.com/darpas-mind-controlled-arm-will-make-you-wish-you-were-1776130193</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Report: Lupita Nyong’o Might Be Showing Up as a Love Interest in the Black Panther Movie</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/5IJXHTPgVL4/report-lupita-nyong-o-might-be-showing-up-as-a-love-in-1776326112</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--6_MoGLQY--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/x5u5kmwinrcnykxdhtrh.jpg" /><p class="first-text">The solo film being built around the King of Wakanda already has Oscar-nominated filmmaker Ryan Coogler attached to direct and write the screenplay. The world’s productivity just took a serious hit.<br /></p><p><a href="http://io9.gizmodo.com/that-excellent-simpsons-quote-search-engine-now-makes-g-1776331156">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/HHR3bWB73QY" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">simpsons</category><category domain="">the simpsons</category><category domain="">frinkiac</category><category domain="">memes</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 20:09:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776331156</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[James Whitbrook]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://io9.gizmodo.com/that-excellent-simpsons-quote-search-engine-now-makes-g-1776331156</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>How Excellent Film Editing Makes Us Feel Luke Skywalker's Failure</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/dVYu1-n0Jeo/how-patient-film-editing-lets-us-feel-luke-skywalkers-f-1776310193</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--Dq2F5wds--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/aq1hwer6a1ztmmm9fsl2.gif" /><p class="first-text">A good movie owes a lot to great writing and acting. But the people responsible for the rhythm of emotional arcs and intimate moments of conflict are rarely if acknowledged. Those people are film editors, and counterintuitively, an editor is often at their best when their work is totally invisible.</p><p><a href="http://sploid.gizmodo.com/how-patient-film-editing-lets-us-feel-luke-skywalkers-f-1776310193">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/dVYu1-n0Jeo" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">movies</category><category domain="">every frame a painting</category><category domain="">tony zhou</category><category domain="">editing</category><category domain="">film</category><category domain="">star wars</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 19:45:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776310193</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Bryan Menegus on Sploid, shared by Adam Clark Estes to io9]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://sploid.gizmodo.com/how-patient-film-editing-lets-us-feel-luke-skywalkers-f-1776310193</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Noomi Rapace to Star in Boy, an Interesting Scifi Thriller With a Terrible, Terrible Title</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/CzEyvDqTQvg/noomi-rapace-to-star-in-boy-an-interesting-scifi-thril-1776316723</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--fJddle1y--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/uzulagag8lxkd9uppkdt.jpg" /><p class="first-text">Noomi Rapace is going to star in a new science fiction thriller called <em>Boy</em>. comfortable revealing on digital trading cards. Yes, cards that are just jpegs on my phone. We’ve <a href="http://io9.gizmodo.com/how-the-hell-is-this-jpg-of-han-solo-worth-225-1726156785">explained the obsession in the past</a>
 <inset id="1726156785" /> but, it’s a rising trend among collectors and now the card company Topps is tackling a new franchise: <em>The Walking Dead</em>.</p><p><a href="http://io9.gizmodo.com/you-can-now-trade-digital-walking-dead-cards-if-youre-1776260885">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/0wuWfCWlVE4" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">the walking dead</category><category domain="">topps</category><category domain="">digital cards</category><category domain="">star wars card trader</category><category domain="">the walking dead card trader</category><category domain="">television</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 19:20:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776260885</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Germain Lussier]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://io9.gizmodo.com/you-can-now-trade-digital-walking-dead-cards-if-youre-1776260885</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>A Huge Unnamed Dwarf Planet, Almost the Size of Pluto, Has Been Hiding in Our Solar System</title><link>http://feeds.gawker.com/~r/io9/full/~3/gY5ZGhLP_Cc/a-huge-unnamed-dwarf-planet-almost-the-size-of-pluto-1776287457</link><description><img src="https://i.kinja-img.com/gawker-media/image/upload/s--491DOXVQ--/c_fit,fl_progressive,q_80,w_636/ygda7fymiduhlot47kcg.jpg" /><p class="first-text">In a universe full of planets, 2007 OR10 is something special. It’s big, just slightly smaller than the size of Pluto. And it’s close, within our very own solar system. So how did it still manage to take astronomers by surprise?</p><p><a href="http://gizmodo.com/a-huge-unnamed-dwarf-planet-almost-the-size-of-pluto-1776287457">Read more...</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/io9/full/~4/gY5ZGhLP_Cc" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></description><category domain="">space</category><category domain="">solar system</category><category domain="">science</category><category domain="">2007 or10</category><category domain="">exoplanets</category><category domain="">kepler</category><category domain="">herschel</category><category domain="">esa</category><category domain="">nasa</category><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 18:28:00 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">1776287457</guid><dc:creator><![CDATA[Ria Misra on Gizmodo, shared by Adam Clark Estes to io9]]></dc:creator><feedburner:origLink>http://gizmodo.com/a-huge-unnamed-dwarf-planet-almost-the-size-of-pluto-1776287457</feedburner:origLink></item></channel></rss>
